newsitem.title: USA: US 30-yr mortgage rate falls below eight pct.
newsitem.headline: US 30-yr mortgage rate falls below eight pct.

text.p: The average commitment rate on U.S. 30-year fixed rate mortgages in the week ending May 9 fell below eight percent for the first time since the end of March, Freddie Mac said Thursday.
Thirty-year mortgages averaged 7.94 percent in the May 9 week. The last time they dipped below eight percent was in the week ended March 28 when they stood at 7.97 percent, it said.
It was also a third consecutive weekly drop for 30-year rates. Last week the 30-year averaged 8.01 percent.

Fifteen-year fixed rate mortgages also fell for the third week in a row to 7.47 percent from 7.53 percent the prior week, while one-year adjustable rate mortgages inched down a fourth consecutive week to 5.82 percent from 5.84 percent.
A year ago, the 30-year rate averaged 8.24 percent, the 15-year 7.75 percent and the ARM 5.80 percent.
"The markets reacted this week to the news of a balanced budget agreement between the White House and Congress," said Robert Van Order, Freddie Mac chief economist.
"The prospect of less government borrowing in the future takes pressure off interest rates, which accounts for the decline we see in these figures this week," Van Order added.
But many analysts expect another rise in interest rates when the Federal Open Market Committee meets May 20.
Last Friday the Labor Department reported a U.S. April unemployment rate of 4.9 percent, the lowest since an identical rate in December 1973.
Lenders charged an average 1.6 percent in fees and points on both 30- and 15-year loans, down from 1.7 percent last week. They charged 1.4 percent on ARM loans, unchanged from last week.
Freddie Mac is a corporation chartered by Congress that buys mortgages from lenders and packages them into securities for investors.
